The $6-Million New Year's Eve Jewelry Heist in Manhattan May Have Been an Inside Job 
Happy 2017! By Sammy Nickalls Jan 3, 2017 To round out 2016 on a proper evil-villain-action-movie note, investigators believe that the $6-million jewelry heist in Manhattan on New Year's Eve may have been the result of an inside job. According to the New York Daily News , police sources said Tuesday that they believe an employee who manufactured the safes containing the jewelry gave the three thieves the combination to the safes. Surveillance images show one of the thieves on a cellphone as he put in the combination to two locked safes on the sixth floor of Gregg Ruth's KGK Holdings in Midtown. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Lacka Safe Co. loaned the safes to KGK Holdings, and only a few people from both companies knew the combination to the safes. However, investigators believe the a "high-ranking employee" at Lacka Safe Co. that has a drug problem provided the intel. "We don't know what happened...we just found out a few hours ago," an unnamed Lacka Safe manager told New York Daily News . "We don't know what to say." Happy 2017!
